title: Freeway & Urban Driving Strategies
objectives: Merge smoothly using acceleration lanes without stopping unless required.
Select the correct freeway lane and use the left lane mainly for passing.
Identify and follow HOV (carpool) and express-lane rules and markings.
Manage speed under California’s basic speed law and changing conditions.
Maintain a safe following distance at freeway speeds and increase it in poor conditions.
Plan exits early, read interchange signs, and handle weaving areas safely.
Scan for urban hazards including intersections, frequent stops, and pedestrians.
Share the road with vulnerable users: bikes, scooters, buses, and light rail.
Apply city parking rules: curb colors, meters, time limits, and hill parking.
Handle special conditions: night glare, rain spray, hydroplaning, wind, and large-vehicle turbulence.

content.text: On-ramps and acceleration lanes exist to help you reach freeway speed before merging. Look far ahead and match the speed of traffic as you approach the merge area.
Use the entire acceleration lane. Do not stop on the ramp unless traffic or a signal requires it. Freeway traffic has the right of way.
Ramp meters are small signals that control how quickly vehicles enter. Obey the posted sign—often it is one vehicle per green per lane. Follow posted signs and local rules.

items: Signal early and check mirrors and over-the-shoulder blind spots.
Choose a gap that does not force others to brake hard.
Merge one lane at a time—do not cross solid lines.
After merging, leave at least a 3‑second following distance.

content.text: Use SMOG: Signal, Mirrors, Over‑the‑shoulder, Go when clear. Enter at or near traffic speed so others do not have to slow suddenly.
If a driver speeds up to block you, keep signaling and adjust to the next gap. Do not stop on the ramp unless a signal or stopped traffic requires it.
When two streams merge, be courteous and take turns if needed. Maintain lane position and communicate with your indicators.

items: Common teen mistakes: stopping on the acceleration lane, looking only in mirrors, entering too slowly, drifting across multiple lanes at once.

lessons.title: Freeway Exits: Off‑ramps, Signals & Shoulder Use

content.text: Know your exit early. Move to the proper lane one at a time and signal for at least five seconds (about 400 ft) before exiting.
Follow any exit‑ramp signals and advisory speeds. Do not cross solid lines or the gore area to make a last‑second exit.
If you miss an exit, keep going to the next one. Never back up on the freeway.

items: Breakdown? Move to the right shoulder, turn on hazards, and stay in the vehicle until help arrives.
Use roadside assistance/FSP where available.

content.text: On multilane roads, the leftmost lane is lane 1, then numbers increase to the right.
Use the left lane mainly for passing or left turns. Use right lanes for entering/exiting and for slower traffic.
Solid white lines mean do not change lanes; broken white lines allow a lane change when safe.

items: Signal, check mirrors, and look over your shoulder.
Change one lane at a time; avoid weaving.
Do not slow unnecessarily before a lane change.

content.text: Pass on the left and return only when you can see the vehicle’s headlights in your rearview mirror.
Passing on the right is allowed only in specific situations (e.g., multiple same‑direction lanes or the other driver turning left). Never drive off the paved roadway to pass.
Do not linger in the left lane. If faster traffic approaches from behind, move right when safe.

items: If being passed, maintain speed and lane position.
Do not speed up to prevent someone from passing.

content.text: HOV lanes are marked with a diamond symbol and signs. They are for vehicles that meet posted occupancy, eligible clean‑air vehicles with DMV decals, and motorcycles (unless posted otherwise).
Never cross double‑solid white lines to enter or exit an HOV lane. Use designated entry/exit areas with broken lines.
Some corridors use express lanes with tolls or transponders. Follow posted signs and local rules.

items: Check posted HOV hours and minimum occupants.
Watch for left‑side HOV ramps and special separators.
Avoid last‑second moves across the buffer.

content.text: Never drive faster than is safe for current conditions, regardless of the posted limit.
Typical maximum freeway speed is 65 mph unless posted otherwise. Slow for traffic, weather, visibility, and roadway surfaces.
Do not impede traffic by driving far below the flow; move right if needed and safe.

items: Be alert for special limits near schools, alleys, and blind intersections.
Always follow posted signs and local rules.

content.text: Use the three‑second rule at a minimum. Increase following distance at higher speeds and in rain, darkness, or heavy spray.
If you are tailgated, keep your pace, then change to a right lane when safe to let the driver pass.
Avoid squeezing into small gaps. After merging, rebuild your space cushion.

items: Pick a fixed point ahead.
When the vehicle ahead passes it, count ‘one‑thousand‑one, two‑three’.
If you reach the point sooner than three, you are following too closely.

lessons.title: Sight Distance, Escape Routes & Space Cushion

content.text: Scan at least 10 seconds ahead to spot slowdowns, debris, and lane drops early.
Avoid driving in other drivers’ blind spots. Create space on both sides whenever possible.
If you cannot see around a large vehicle, increase following distance or change lanes when safe.

items: When hazards are on both sides, handle one at a time—slow down for oncoming traffic, then pass a cyclist with extra room.
Keep an ‘out’—know where you can safely go if the lane ahead closes.

content.text: Interchanges (cloverleaf, diamond, trumpet) connect roads using ramps with curves and changing speeds. Expect limited sight distance on ramps.
Large broken lines often mark lane ends and exits. Watch for ‘EXIT ONLY’ and lane‑drop signs.
Weaving areas occur where entering and exiting paths cross. Look ahead, communicate with signals, and be patient.

items: Read guide signs early.
Adjust speed before the curve.
Stay in your lane through ramps; avoid last‑second moves.

content.text: Move to the proper lane well before your exit. Signal for at least five seconds (about 400 ft) to communicate your intent.
Respect solid lines and gore areas. If you miss the exit, continue to the next one—never back up.
In weaving segments, take turns (‘zipper’) and avoid accelerating to block others.

items: Check blind spots before lane changes.
Watch for trucks and give them extra room to exit or merge.

content.text: City streets have many close intersections. Expect frequent red lights and stop‑and‑go traffic.
Pedestrians have the right of way in marked and unmarked crosswalks. Yield and scan both sides.
Treat dark signals as all‑way stops. Do not enter an intersection unless you can fully clear it.

items: Cover the brake near crosswalks.
Check left‑right‑left before moving.
Watch for turning vehicles and cyclists.

content.text: Expect delivery trucks, buses, and ride‑share vehicles to stop at curbs. People may walk out between vehicles.
Double‑parking is illegal. Never stop in a travel lane to load/unload.
Leave extra space on the right side of your lane and be ready to stop. Doors can open suddenly.

items: If a bike lane is blocked, merge out carefully and yield to cyclists.
You may enter a bike lane within 200 ft of a right turn; check blind spots first.

content.text: Bicycles share the road and may use the full lane when needed. Give them space and expect speed changes.
Leave at least three feet when passing. Change lanes to pass when necessary and safe.
The ‘door zone’ is hazardous. Check mirrors and over your shoulder before opening doors near traffic or bike lanes.

items: Never park in a bike lane.
Enter the bike lane within 200 ft of a right turn and yield to cyclists.
Watch for e‑scooters and slow riders near curbs.

lessons.title: Bus‑Only Lanes, Light Rail & Transit Stops

content.text: Do not drive, stop, or park in a bus‑only lane. You may cross it to turn right where permitted.
At marked safety zones for streetcars or trolleys, pass at no more than 10 mph and watch for people.
Do not pass light rail on the left unless directed. Look for trains before crossing tracks.

items: Yield to buses reentering traffic when safe.
Follow posted transit signals and local rules.

content.text: Curb colors: white = pick up/drop‑off, green = time‑limited, yellow = loading/commercial, red = no stopping, blue = disabled parking with placard/plates.
Read signs and meters for hours and time limits. Always follow posted signs and local rules.
Park within 18 inches of the curb when parallel parking.

items: Watch for tow‑away or street‑cleaning restrictions.
Stop only briefly in white zones, and load/unload only as allowed in yellow zones.

content.text: On hills: turn wheels toward the curb when facing downhill; away from the curb when uphill; with no curb, turn toward the edge.
Parallel park by aligning, backing at ~45°, straightening, and ending within 18 inches of the curb.
Never park in crosswalks, in front of driveways, too close to hydrants, or in double‑parked positions.

items: Blue spaces require a placard/plate.
Red curbs and bus zones prohibit stopping.

content.text: Use low beams in rain or fog and whenever wipers are on. Never drive with only parking lights.
At night, look to the right edge to avoid glare and slow so you can stop within the distance you can see.
In heavy rain, reduce speed and watch for standing water. If you begin to hydroplane, ease off the accelerator and avoid hard braking or sudden turns.

items: If you cannot see 100 ft ahead in heavy rain or snow, it is not safe to drive faster than about 30 mph.

content.text: Large vehicles create wind turbulence and have big blind spots. Do not linger beside them. Pass on the left and do not cut in.
Strong winds: slow down, grip the wheel, and be alert for debris. Avoid cruise control in gusty conditions.
If your vehicle breaks down, move to the right shoulder, turn on hazards, call for help (511/FSP where available), and stay in the vehicle with your seat belt fastened.

items: During a traffic break, turn on hazards and slow to the patrol car’s speed until the lights turn off.
